doc.title: PREDATOR

description.text: Protein secondary structure prediction from a single sequence or a set of sequences

doc.reference: Frishman, D. and Argos, P. (1996) Incorporation of long-distance interactions into a secondary structure prediction algorithm. Protein Engineering, 9, 133-142.
Frishman, D. and Argos, P. (1997) 75% accuracy in protein secondary structure prediction. Proteins, 27, 329-335.
Frishman,D and Argos,P. (1995) Knowledge-based secondary structure assignment. Proteins: structure, function and genetics, 23, 566-579.
Kabsch,W. and Sander,C. (1983) Dictionary of protein secondary structure: pattern recognition of hydrogen-bonded and geometrical features. Biopolymers, 22: 2577-2637.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: You must enter either a protein sequences or alignment file

fieldset.title: This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.

xhtml:div.label: Perform single sequence prediction. Ignore other sequences in the set for computing the prediction (-s) Yes No

Do not copy assignment directly from the PDB database (-u)?
Yes No
Do not copy assignment directly from the PDB database if query sequence is found in PDB. By default, the known conformation of 7-residue segments will be used if they are identical to a 7-residue fragment in the query sequence.

Use DSSP target assignment (-d)?
Yes No
Use DSSP target assignment (default is STRIDE). The predictions made with DSSP and STRIDE target assignments are optimized to reproduce these assignments as well as possible.
Find a subset of sequences with no more than this identity between any pair of sequences (-n)
Make prediction for All sequences in the input file (-a) Yes No

Make prediction for this sequence (give its id) (-i)?
This option is case sensitive!

label.title: This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.

xhtml:div.label: PDB Chain (-z)

Long output form (-l)?
Yes No
Every output line contains residue number, three-letter residue name, one-letter residue name, predicted secondary structural state and reliability estimate. If a STRIDE or DSSP secondary structure assignment has been read (see other options), the known assignment will also be shown in the output for comparison. By default the short output form is used.
Output other additional information if available (-h) Yes No

div.title: This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Do not copy assignment directly from the PDB database if query sequence is found in PDB. By default, the known conformation of 7-residue segments will be used if they are identical to a 7-residue fragment in the query sequence.
Use DSSP target assignment (default is STRIDE). The predictions made with DSSP and STRIDE target assignments are optimized to reproduce these assignments as well as possible.
This option is case sensitive!

div.title: This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Every output line contains residue number, three-letter residue name, one-letter residue name, predicted secondary structural state and reliability estimate. If a STRIDE or DSSP secondary structure assignment has been read (see other options), the known assignment will also be shown in the output for comparison. By default the short output form is used.
Short output form:
Secondary structure states of amino acids are indicated by the letters "H" (helix), "E" (extended or sheet), and "_" (coil).
Long output form ( option -L selected ):

Secondary structure states of amino acids are indicated by letters "H" or "h" (helix), "E" or "e" (extended), and "C" or "c" (coil). The prediction is shown in lower case except for those residues for which the assignment was directly copied from the PDB database. This feature is added so that you can distinguish between the predictions actually made by PREDATOR and those taken from known structures. The prediction is contained in the records beginning with the identifier PRED in the first columns. For each amino acid site of your sequence, residue number, three- and one-letter residue code, prediction, reliability estimate, and the number of residues from related sequences projected onto this residue through the local alignment procedure are shown in subsequent columns. Additionally, if the STRIDE or DSSP assignments have been read using the options -x or -y (and -z), the last column of the PREDATOR output will contain the actual secondary structural assignment for your sequence if it corresponds exactly to the one in the STRIDE or DSSP file (for comparison). If the known assignment is not available, i.e., if you did not use the -x or -y options, question signs will be output.
Both output forms:

If option -h has been used, PREDATOR will show progress by printing dots on the standard output. If your sequence has related sequences with known 3D structure, PDB identifiers of these sequences will be printed.

comment.text: You must enter either a protein sequences or alignment file

precond.code: sequences is not None and alignment is None

message.text: You must fill either sequences or alignment not both

div.title: This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.

precond.code: alignment is not None and sequences is None

message.text: You must fill either alignment or sequences not both

Yes No

comment.text: Secondary structure states of amino acids are indicated by the letters "H" (helix), "E" (extended or sheet), and "_" (coil).

Secondary structure states of amino acids are indicated by letters "H" or "h" (helix), "E" or "e" (extended), and "C" or "c" (coil). The prediction is shown in lower case except for those residues for which the assignment was directly copied from the PDB database. This feature is added so that you can distinguish between the predictions actually made by PREDATOR and those taken from known structures. The prediction is contained in the records beginning with the identifier PRED in the first columns. For each amino acid site of your sequence, residue number, three- and one-letter residue code, prediction, reliability estimate, and the number of residues from related sequences projected onto this residue through the local alignment procedure are shown in subsequent columns. Additionally, if the STRIDE or DSSP assignments have been read using the options -x or -y (and -z), the last column of the PREDATOR output will contain the actual secondary structural assignment for your sequence if it corresponds exactly to the one in the STRIDE or DSSP file (for comparison). If the known assignment is not available, i.e., if you did not use the -x or -y options, question signs will be output.

If option -h has been used, PREDATOR will show progress by printing dots on the standard output. If your sequence has related sequences with known 3D structure, PDB identifiers of these sequences will be printed.
